title: Resisting images of the ‘diminished self’: the implications of emotional well‐being and emotional engagement in education policy
abstract: Abstract Developing people’s emotional well‐being and emotional engagement are official aims in social policy. A growing number of initiatives respond to diverse, often contradictory public, political and professional concerns about individuals’ emotional needs. These concerns are a powerful discourse in ‘personalised learning’. The article contributes to debates in critical policy research. It evaluates the subtle ways in which policy initiatives to develop emotional well‐being and encourage emotional engagement with public services resonate with images of the ‘diminished self’ emerging in broader cultural discourses. Critical evaluation is necessary in order for researchers and educators committed to social justice to challenge the influential idea that emotional well‐being should be a prominent educational goal and to resist the diminished images of human potential that underlie it. Acknowledgements I am grateful to Laura Bell and Brahm Norwich (University of Exeter) and Paul Newton (Qualifications and Curriculum Authority) for detailed comments on an earlier draft of this article. A large number of people have also taken time and trouble to debate themes covered in the article and have provided many illuminating insights and counter arguments: Debbie Morgan and Gert Biesta (University of Exeter), Jocey Quinn (London Metropolitan University), Ann‐Marie Bathmaker (University of West England), Helen Colley (Manchester Metropolitan University), John Vorhaus and Jay Derrick (National Research and Development Centre for Adult Literacy and Numeracy), Dennis Hayes (Canterbury Christchurch University), Pat Thomson and Kate Wilson (University of Nottingham), Julie Ecclestone and David Glover (Oxfordshire Social Services), Patrick Ainley (University of Greenwich) and Patrick Turner (Wandsworth Youth Service).
